reviewText:
1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Love (for blood) never dies
Frogware - the team behind the Sherlock Holmes point and click adventures, return with a game based on Bram Stokers Dracula. Having loved the novel from a very early age and adored the Francis Ford Coppola interpretation to screen I am very well versed in the tale of Count Dracula and his abandonment of his faith to become a vampire. Dracula, with all its elements of horror, still to this day remains one of the most enduring love stories of our time and I have lost count the amount of times I have read the original novel or watched the 1993 Oscar winning movie.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=345591197
The game doesn't follow the novel to the tee and makes some diversions in plot and characterization which I was honestly fine with since this is an interactive medium. I don't play as many point and click adventures as I would like to these days (It used to be my favorite genre when Sierra and Lucas Arts ruled the gaming roost) so I really enjoyed my time with the game more than I probably would any other adventure game purely because of the Dracula connection. In terms of gameplay it's the standard adventure fare where the player must collect items and use them in conjunction with various other items, characters or places to move the tale along. Also, as with every adventure game known to man, there are some puzzles which simply defy any kind of logic and its a matter of trying various combinations to pass them which can get very tiresome and rather frustrating.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=345592284
At just over 10 hours of gameplay, the game doesn't overstay its welcome either. Story and voice acting could have done with a bit of tightening and control. Van Helsing is all over the place tonally often sounding far too excited when he is simply being offered a cup of tea or bored to death when chasing down Dracula for the showdown. The graphics aren't exactly revolutionary but you don't need Nvidia Titans for adventure games so they end up being more than serviceable.

If you enjoy the Dracula myth and/or puzzle adventure games then give it a try. I can definitely recommend this title.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText: I went into this knowing full well what I was walking into. If you've played Still Life, Art of Murder or Sherlock Holmes you know what kind of game this is. It's a casual puzzle game with story enough to make you want to see what happens. This isn't a game you want if you are a die hard on graphic quality.\n\nI would recommend this game to anyone just looking for a game to pass the time with.
voteText: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is a prequel to the “Dracula: Love Kills” (although “Love Kills” start contradicts the “Origin's” ending).

“Dracula: Origin” has a rather beautiful design and interesting story with some nice variations of the classic Stoker's novel, although I felt a bit bored in the beginning and, at one point, thought of quitting the game completely.

As to the puzzles, they are either too simple, or too difficult and rely heavily on trial and error and dialogue re-reading, which I personally found unconventional and inconvenient.

Also, it's easy to miss items, leading you to often re-visiting of the same spots and circling around, moving the cursor carefully across the screen.

As many of the puzzles do not follow a straightforward one path logic or any logic at all, this walkthough guide is highly recommended to save time and avoid frustration: http://www.gameboomers.com/wtcheats/pcDd/draculaorigin.htm

I played it for the story anyway. Not the best puzzles and clues in the genre.

My overall rating: 6/10. The sequel is much better.

reviewText:
Such a bad, borring game.

It's a straight forward point-and-click adventure game, but the puzzles are easy for the player to figure out; at least they are when the obvious solution actualy works.
For example, you can't enter an area because it's dark. *use matches on lantern* Nope.
*Use lantern on matches* Nope
*Use lantern on dark cave entrance* Nope
The correct option is to light the matches and drop the lit pack at the entrance. Because ligthing all your matches and leaving them in a burning pile at the door makes perfect sense when you have a lantern.

The other problem is that you will figure out the puzzle and the solution to whatever your doing before your character does. If you don't scrape away every pixel from that tombstone, he won't read it and if you enter the answer to the riddle yourself it just won't work. The player character is dumber than you, and you're not allowed to play smart.

I paid about 99 cents for this game and still feel ripped off.

reviewText: Dracula Origin is a decent puzzle game.  Buy it on sale or in a bundle.  USE SPACE TO SEE WHAT YOU CAN CLICK.  The game nowhere I could find tells you to use space to see what objects are interactive.  Once I figured this out the game got a lot more fun.  Some of the puzzles are fairly easy, some are quite diffiuclt, and one in particular is just insane.  I used a walktrhough for the last puzzle mentioned.  The graphics are decent and the interface is passable yet clunky and confusing at times.  Some of the puzzles use items in ways that nobody in the real world would ever use them.  Using a dead badger carcass as a wine tube for instance.  Sometimes I felt somewhat angry because logic went out the window on a few of the puzzles.  Being made to click through every item in your inventory to find the right one gets old real fast, especially when a more obvious choice is in your inventory.  Hrmmm...should I use the sword to break the lock or the throat lozenge?  Yeah that's right...the throat lozenge.......\n\nOVERALL:  5.5/10

reviewText:
Hell,
I love this game!!!!
Has hidden objects & really works my mind. It's nothing like those stupid games on Pogo.com my mother trys to get me to play. I really enjoyed this game & it's also goes with the few games that actually keeps my attention & interest well enough to play it all the way through.
I've been playing games since a kid when Nintendo, Segs Dreamcast, even Atari came out on Doctors recomendations due to a consitration & focusing problem I have.
So, even as a 37 year old it's still hard to find games to help with those problems when they actually can't keep your interest long enough.

I will recommend this game especially for those who have the same problems I do.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dracula Origin for me presented an interesting and enjoyable story in settings that varied greatly and  where both interesting to explore and well designed. The puzzels presented within Dracula vary in difficulty and complexity and the style of them also changes depending on the location you are in, this is a nice touch and keeps the game moving and engaging for the around 2 - 3 hours you are in a certain area. The story within the game follows a rather cliche plot, and ends abruptly however its enough to keep you going, however for an adventure game where story is usually a mian factor it is a bit of a let down. The sound design is great, with different background music  playing in different areas and ambient noise creating a creepy atmosphere which suits the overall theme of the game.

Overall Dracula Origin is a well designed adventure game and did as a whole keep me interested, I would recommend this game to anyone wanting a casual adventure game that does not last to long but overall tells a short creepy story with clever puzzels. For me $10 is a good price for fun experience you will get, however if you are not that into adventure games I would recommend waiting for a sale.

Overall 8/10.

reviewText: Good point and click adventure game.  Puzzles were challenging, the voice acting was decent, the atmosphere was perfect for a gothic vampire theme.  I appreciated how the puzzles reflected the game and weren't stand alone like in many other games; for example, you had to figure out the demons from normal animals or puzzles relating to dark arts.  The music was okay, it got a little repetitive when trying to figure out a puzzle.  My only complaint is I think they took out the see through top of the succubus from this game.  You can find it in a couple of screenshots, but after playing the game recently I think they just zoomed in on her face for that particular scene.  I was waiting to screenshot it myself! Censorship is kind of annoying.   The story was great too adding to the historical lore of Dracula in detail. Overall 7.5/10

reviewText:
As an early entry in the Frogwares catalogue, Dracula Origin isn't anything to shout about. Many of the puzzles are recycled (or will later be recycled in future games), the soundtrack is sparse and repetitive, paths are poorly defined, and your character, Van Helsing, is simply boring to play as.
His bland delivery and perpetual hand-clasping animations do little to make the depiction a memorable one, and although the man is righteous and sincere, he could stand to be a bit more interesting. I can't help thinking that bad translation has contributed to this a great deal.
The game isn't riddled with faults apart from the items being somewhat hard to see and the aforementioned bad placement of directions; as a plus, the backgrounds are pleasant to look at.

Overall: Meh.

reviewText:
A 3D point and click game.

Despite looking graphicly ok and sounding pretty decent, the experience of the game is lacking.

The gameplay seems really dull when it comes to horror and action which is surprising when it has dracula in the title. You know the Daddy of all vampires, the guy who's supposed to be one mean scary creature of the night who will tear you a new one! yeah that guy's no where to be seen D:

In fact it is the total opposite, you do not see dracula at all after the opening of the game until the very end. For the action and horror situations throughout the game, you say? Get about the same result from watching a lone goldfish in a small fish bowl. This game would struggle to scare a small child.

Genral gameplay, however  is pretty good. The controlls are smooth and the interface is simple.

The game also does have good challanging puzzles amongst some what good graphics and sounds, but this is not suppose to be just a puzzle game.

Overall the game is dull and boring but has tough puzzles.

so if your looking for a tough puzzle game, forget about buying that 2000 jigsaw of fruit in a bowl from amazon, waste your money on this game.  It will be about as boring and dull but you don't have to pick up all pieces when you give up 10 mintues in.


1/10 - it did manage to trick me into buying it so ill give it that.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. I like Dracula, the book, and a couple movie versions. (Dracula 2000, the original Bela Lugosi one)
I've also liked different people's takes on Dracula. Castlevania: Symphony of the Night for example was hardly true to the source material but still succeeding in making Dracula an interesting character and being in general an awesome game.
This... this was not.
They diverged from the traditional Dracula storylines, but never in interesting ways. The gameplay itself was boring as hell.
I want there to be a good game about Dracula, I really really do. It could be awesome. But this isn't it.
If you want a story based vampire fix, go play VtM Bloodlines.

reviewText: Commits the classic no'no's of adventure games, illogical puzzles and overly-pricise puzzles (that's a puzzle that won't complete unless you've drawn, placed or down something in a very specific way yet is very open ended and comes with little to no guidance to insure you do it 100% right in the first place).\n\nSimply put I had to youtube the first puzzle (the map drawing one) and 4th or so puzzle because it was cryptic / random. If you have to do that so early so often it's the early indication of a poor adventure game I'm afraid. Of course if you don't mind / care about solving the puzzles yourself (a core mechanic in my opinion) it's probably still going to be a good game for you.

reviewText: Kinda boring. I played The Testament of Sherlock Holmes first from the same developers before, that was a lot more enjoyable and modern. In this one the player doesn't have a free camera and it was annoying. I admit I never read the original novel, but the game's story is bland (the thousandth iteration of damsel in distress - yawn) the characters are not even two, but one-dimensional. I can't say they put any effort in the game aside of the visuals. (One scene that stood out as particularly beautiful is the Viennese library <3) Overall my rating is 2/5, kinda bland, boring game, not engaging, but not overly horrible either. Some of the puzzles and situations didn't make sense (like when the solution of a scene was that the player has to set a person on fire. yes.)

reviewText:
This game was cheap enough that I didn't mind playing it through to the end, but that doesn't mean I'd recommend it.

The production values are shoddy and it suffers from the fault of many a point and click adventure that it's all so linear you spend your time waiting for your character to catch up with your conclusions. There are also a number of counterintuitive puzzles and you have to spend a lot of time moving your mouse over every inch of the screen to find the stupid items.

If you have nothing better to do, buy this one on sale.

reviewText: Tried this game out because I'm a HUGE fan of Frogware's Sherlock Holmes games. This one was a bit better than Dracula: Love Kills both in difficulty and storyline. It wasn't just a 'search for this object type of game.\n\nIn many ways
date:
it resembled most of the Sherlock Holmes games (Minus Hounds of Baskerville which resembled Love Kills) in that you had to look for documents and interview people while searching for clues as well.

And this slight difficulty made this game more fun.

Took me 9 hours to beat the game rather than the 4 hours I spent to beat the sequel so... I would say this is more worth my money than the second. (1+USD an hour for gameplay. hm...)"

reviewText:
Despite the fact that the game comes from a company, that uses to make and sometimes publish games for companies like Big Fish Games, I would say it's a Pretty Good Adventure!

So let's take things from start. The graphics of the game are a little bit older than 2008 that the game was launched. They're very tolerable if you consider the company as such I presaid. But as this company also created all the Sherlock Holmes Series I would say that I expected more at this point, even from the older Sherlock Holmes games. Maybe they didn't have the funds because when Focus Home Interactive published the last Sherlock Holmes creations of Frogwares the games in the graphic sector were totally different.
Don't try any more settings than the given as you'll NOT see any difference. The game is played in 4:3 resolution monitors. Yes, even to that they miscalculated. I played the game in my widescreen 1920x1080 monitor without streching the picture and I would say that I lost a riddle and used a walkthrough because I couldn't make the letters on a notepad to decypher a text. You'll aso laugh at start when you see your character without a shadow.
The videos are looking good and fair. You'll not have issues there comparing to the game resolution.

The sounds are fair too. The voices are fair enough to the overall quality of the game. Though, I would say it has very few music tracks. BUT they all match the scenes very well.

The story is very interesting. Really Dracula. You'll love it and it will keep you playing till the end. The style as written may be Gothic but what you'll see is sometimes AGAINST Gods Will and humanity. So, please, DON'T gift this game to children and completely FORBID them to buy it. Even teenagers or adults with fragile stomach will be affected by the scenes. We talk about Rituals"
recommended: tortures. That kind of things.\nBack to the story I would say that it unfolds as much as you search. It is the only way to progress. You can NOT avoid it. To solve the riddles the game has to be triggerred that you know the facts. So
hoursPlayed: keep it in mind. And you'll find it very interesting. You maybe compare it to the book. I started the game as I thought it was a lite one but it took me about 13 hours with solving all puzzles except two. The first reason was about resolution and the second because in a riddle the game was NOT specific enough(picture with wolves). The ONLY GREAT disappointment.. A very short END.\n\nThe riddles are good for an adventure. Like the style of "Big Fish Games" in deeper thinking tricks and Hard tracks. Many puzzles awaited to be solved by the adventurers. BUT they are NOT so Hard anyway. Common logic and many tries to figure out the logic of the puzzle as professor Van Helsing says all the time. I didn't use a walkthrough in any of them except the ones presaid. If you want you can use the SPACE key to reveal the interaction areas

reviewText:
Even more than other Frogwares games, Dracula: Origin has a wonderfully unique 19th century European mood and aesthetic. The scenes are beautiful and the art direction is supurb. The music is good and the voice work is excellent, particularly for van Helsing.

Van Helsing is a very memorable character: sincerely Catholic, courtly and aloof, intellectual, and possessed of a dry, melodramatic wit. Touring old Europe and Arabia as this character is great fun, and offers the player a completely different experience from the typical American or Japanese game.

(The puzzles are interesting and original, although some of them are unclear and more likely to be solved by accident.)

reviewText:
What Dracula origin is: it is a puzzle intense point-and-click adventure.  It contains character's from Bram Stoker's novel. What Dracula:Origin is not: it is not a first person or third-person shooter.  It does not stay faithful to the novel.

It has about ten cut scenes.  Other than that it is all point and click.  Be diligent and mouse-over and click everything.  There are some very small action boxes.  There are some things you will not be interact with until you have all the necessary information.

It is enjoyable if you like puzzles.  If you are looking for sexy vampires and lots of blood and action check out other title.  I did enjoy and finish this game in about 40 hours of play time.  I did use a walkthrough to help me on some of the more complex troubles.

reviewText:
Dracula Origin is an interesting take on the Dracula myth, brought to you by Frogwares, who are responsible for the relatively recent slew of (pretty good) Sherlock Holmes games (and for creepy Watson). This isn't quite on par with their detective-centric offerings, but it's okay, and unintentionally hilarious at several points.

As the the title of the game would indicate, Dracula Origin explains how everyone's favorite vampire got into the blood-sucking immortality business, and why. A lot of globetrotting, in part to try and save one of Drac's victims, uncovers a trail of mystical entanglements and less-than-ideal choices made by several parties that unleashed the vampiric curse upon the world.

There's not that much to say for the game, in fairness. It's a fun if not particularly memorable romp, with decent puzzles and nothing too frustrating. The frequent changes of scenery are a nice touch, and the story reads well enough, despite being a bit cliche. In some ways, I feel the game's core revelation kind of takes the ♥♥♥♥ out of Dracula, and one wonders if he'd be wearing a fedora and making whiny YouTube videos had either been invented in his time. And if he were real. i guess that's a sticking point as well.

But yeah, it's okay. You could play worse.

Here's what I was talking about re: fedoras, by the way. It's technically a spoiler, but the very description of the game spoils the same thing, so... eh. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ty38m8nnyfY
